Another external attack\nis if an adversary owns a firewall surrounding some of the nodes in the\nnetwork, which it can use to block or delay messages.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;A\nconsensus algorithm is characterized as BFT \u2013 ( Byzantine Fault Tolerance\n)--&nbsp; if it guarantees a moment in time\nwhere all participants reach consensus, know that consensus has been reached,\nand they are never wrong.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">This can be contrasted with consensus algorithms\nbased on PoW, where participants slowly become more and more confident that\nconsensus is near, but may still not be correct.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">There are different levels of\nBFT, depending on the sorts of assumptions made about the network and\ntransmission of messages. The strongest type of BFT is asynchronous BFT.\nHashgraph is unique in supporting highest degree of BFT while still being very\nefficient.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">When a system is asynchronous BFT, it allows\nfor malicious actors controlling the network, deleting or slowing down messages\nof their choosing. The only assumption made is that less than \u2153 are attackers,\nand some messages eventually get transmitted over the internet.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;Some systems\nare partially asynchronous, which are secure only if the attackers do not have\ntoo much power and do not manipulate the timing of messages too much.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">For\ninstance, a partially asynchronous system could prove Byzantine under the\nassumption that messages get passed over the internet in ten seconds. This\nassumption ignores the reality of botnets, distributed denial of service\nattacks, and malicious firewalls.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">If unable to meet the criteria of\nasynchronous BFT, it is preferable that they be asynchronous\nless-than-Byzantine, rather than less-than-asynchronous Byzantine. In other\nwords, they should prove they are somewhat secure in the real world instead of\nproving they are very secure in a fantasy world.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">A Sybil attack refers to an attempt to\ncompromise a network through the creation of large numbers of spurious\nidentities \u2013 these are directed to act in collusion to inappropriately impact\nthe network.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Sybil attacks are a particular concern for public DLTs in which no\nspecial permissions are required to become a node. Hashgraph inherently\nprotects against Sybil attacks due to the nature of the core consensus\nalgorithm which provides a mathematical guarantee that Sybil attacks cannot\nsucceed as long as less than one-third of the population is dishonest.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">There is\na mathematical proof that one-third is the best that can be achieved by any\nDLT.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack\noccurs when it is possible to disrupt the flow of transactions for the entire\nnetwork by targeting a single or a few computers. Different DLTs vary in their\nvulnerability to DDoS.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Leader-based systems give special permissions to a\nparticular node and are highly susceptible because the current leader is a\nbottleneck and is vulnerable to being targeted in the DDoS. Even if the role of\nthe leader rotates amongst nodes, other nodes necessarily know the current\nleader, and so could direct a DDoS.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">PoW systems are resilient to DDoS because\nit\u2019s difficult to predict which miner will solve the inverse hash and publish a\nblock. Consequently, the attacker would not know which miner should be\ntargeted.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Hashgraph doesn\u2019t use PoW, but neither does it have a Leader.&nbsp; &nbsp;So\nHashgraph provides DDoS resilience without the inefficiency and cost of PoW.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Fairness refers to the ability of DLTs to\nprevent the ordering of transactions from being unduly manipulated.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Hashgraph\nis fair in that it serializes all transactions with cryptographic timestamping,\nunlike blockchains where miners determine the order in which transactions are\nplaced within each block. In certain use cases, the transaction order is\nimportant.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Consider for instance two different people purchasing shares in a\nstock \u2013 the first order to go through will likely get a cheaper price. Hashgraph\norders transactions according to the median timestamp of&nbsp; when the population of nodes received them \u2013\nthereby ensuring they are recorded fairly.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Hashgraph Distributed Consensus Platform\nEnables Developers to Build Serverless, Secure Apps in the Cloud.. Swirlds is a\nsoftware platform designed to build fully-distributed applications that harness\nthe power of the cloud without servers.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Now you can develop applications with\nfairness in decision making, speed, trust and reliability, at a fraction of the\ncost of traditional server-based platforms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Java is a general purpose programming\nlanguage with a large open source ecosystem and resources for developer\nsupport.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">There are also advantageous security measures in the Java development\nenvironment, such as sandboxing,&nbsp; that\nwill allow the platform in the future to run untrusted applications, while\nprotecting the user and their hard drive from those applications.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In addition to Java, they want the option for\ndevelopers who would like to develop in other programming languages, such as\nPython or JavaScript. This is part of the Hashgraph development roadmap.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Hashgraphs &nbsp;technology is cost-effective, as it doesn\u2019t\nrequire proof of work like Bitcoin does. It also is quicker, with a transaction\nthroughput of 50,000 times that of most blockchains.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The mathematically proven\nfairness of Hashgraph means that no individual can manipulate the order of\ntransactions. &nbsp;Miners prioritize\ntransactions based on network fees in the cryptocurrency world.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\">In Bitcoin, transaction fees are used to\nincentivize miners to confirm transactions by including them in a block which\nis then appended to the previous blocks, creating a \u2018block chain\u2019.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Hashgraph utilizes virtual voting, which\ndoesn\u2019t require actual votes. Instead, hashgraph uses Gossip to determine how\nnodes would vote. In this system, every node will know what other nodes know\nand when they knew it.</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The blockchain model has five key problems in\nits implementation. These include the issues of scalability, processing power\nand time, storage, a skills gap, and legal and compliance issues.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">All of the nodes that maintain the blockchain\ndo exactly the same thing. Here is what millions of computers do:--<i><o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">They verify the same transactions in\naccordance with the same rules and perform identical operations.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">They record the same thing into a blockchain\n(if they were fortunate enough to be allowed to do so).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">They store the entire history, which is the\nsame for all of them, for all time.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">There is no paralleling, no synergy, and no\nmutual assistance. There is only instant, millionfold duplication.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">It\u2019s the\nopposite of efficient and is IMMATURE<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">If each network node does the same thing,\nthen obviously, the bandwidth of the entire network is the same as the\nbandwidth of one network node. But do you know exactly what that is?&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">The\nBitcoin network is capable of processing a maximum of seven transactions per\nsecond \u2014 for the millions of users worldwide.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">Aside from that, Bitcoin-blockchain\ntransactions are recorded only once every 10 minutes. To increase payments\nsecurity, it is standard practice to wait 50 minutes more after each new record\nappears because the records regularly roll back</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">You have &nbsp;heard of miners and giant mining farms built\nnext to power stations?&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">What do they actually do?&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">They burn a lot of\nelectricity for no purpose at all for 10 minutes, \u201cshaking\u201d blocks until they\nbecome \u201cbeautiful\u201d and thus eligible to be added to a blockchain..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\">The\nelectricity consumed to achieve that is the same as the amount a city with a\npopulation of 100,000 people would use.&nbsp; &nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\">APCO Modi want to use wind and solar power--&nbsp; TEE HEEEEEE .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">And don\u2019t forget the expensive custom\nmining equipment, which is almost useless for any purpose other than mining\nbitcoins.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Blockchain optimists like to say that miners\nmaintain the stability and security of the Bitcoin network. This is true, but\nthe problem is that miners are protecting Bitcoin from other miners.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">If only one-thousandth of the current number\nof miners existed, and thus one-thousandth of the electric power was consumed,\nthen Bitcoin would be just as good as it is now.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">It would still produce one\nblock per 10 minutes, process the same number of transactions, and operate at\nexactly the same speed.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">The risk of a 51% attack applies to blockchain\nsolutions as well.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">If someone controls more than half of the computing power\ncurrently being used for mining, then that person can surreptitiously write an\nalternative financial history.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">That version then becomes reality. Thus, it\nbecomes possible to spend the same money more than once. Traditional payment\nsystems are immune to such an attack.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">Bitcoin has become a prisoner of its own\nideology.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\u201cExcessive\u201d miners cannot stop mining; that would dramatically\nincrease the probability of a single person controlling more than half of the\nremaining computing power.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Mining is still lucrative, and the network is still\nstable.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">However, if the situation changes (if, for example, the price of\nelectricity increases), the network may come across a huge number of \u201cdouble\nspending\u201d incidents.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">All \u201cindependent\u201d miners are merged into\npools (technically, they\u2019re cartels).&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">They have to merge on the assumption that\nit\u2019s better to have a small but stable income than a huge payoff maybe every\nthousand years<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\">Blockchain is open, and everyone sees\neverything.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\">Thus, blockchain has no real anonymity.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\">It offers pseudonymity\ninstead.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Putting aside the significant issues that crooked users have with\nthat, here\u2019s why pseudonymity is bad for honest users.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">A simple example: I am\ntransferring a few bitcoins to my mother. Here\u2019s what she can learn:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">How much money I have at any given time.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">How much I spent and, more important, what I\nspent it on. She could also find out what I bought, what I gambled on, and what\npolitician I supported \u201canonymously.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Alternatively, if I paid back my friend for\nsome lemonade, I would thus let him know everything about my finances. That\u2019s\nhardly a trifling matter:&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">Would you reveal the financial history of your credit\ncard to everyone you knew?&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">Keep in mind that this would include not only past\nbut also future transactions.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Some disclosure may be tolerable for\nindividuals, but it is deadly for companies.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">All of their contracting parties,\nsales, customers, account amounts, and every other little, petty detail would\nall become public.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Financial transparency is perhaps one of the largest\ndisadvantages of using Bitcoin.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">So so so&nbsp;\nif someone tells you that the invention of the blockchain-ULU ( or is it\nblockchin-UDU ) &nbsp;can be compared with the\ninvention of the Internet in terms of importance\u2014 tell him &nbsp;BALLS !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">If a blockchain is not a robust network with\na widely distributed grid of nodes, it becomes more difficult to reap the full\nbenefit.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">If a blockchain is used as a database, the information going into the\ndatabase needs to be of high quality. The data stored on a blockchain is not\ninherently trustworthy, so events need to be recorded accurately in the first\nplace.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">The phrase 'garbage in, garbage out' holds\ntrue in a blockchain system of record, just as with a centralized database.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">There\nis one notable security flaw in bitcoin and other blockchains: if more than\nhalf of the computers working as nodes to service the network tell a lie, the\nlie will become the truth.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">This is called a '51% attack' and was highlighted by\nSatoshi Nakamoto when he launched bitcoin.&nbsp; &nbsp;For this reason, bitcoin mining pools\nare monitored closely by the community, ensuring no one unknowingly gains such\nnetwork influence.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">A smart contract is a piece of code that is\nstored on an blockchain, triggered by blockchain transactions and which reads\nand writes data in that blockchain's database. That's it !<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">A smart contract is just a fancy name for\ncode that runs on a blockchain, and interacts with that blockchain's state.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The problem with smart contracts isn\u2019t just\nthat people\u2019s expectations are overblown, it's that these expectations are\nleading many to spend time and money on ideas that cannot possibly be\nimplemented.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Often, the first use case proposed is a smart\ncontract that changes its behavior in response to some external event. For\nexample, an agricultural insurance policy which pays out conditionally based on\nthe quantity of rainfall in a given month.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The imagined process goes something like\nthis: The smart contract waits until the predetermined time, retrieves the\nweather report from an external service and behaves appropriately based on the\ndata received.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">This all sounds simple enough, but it\u2019s also\nimpossible. Why? Because a blockchain is a consensus-based system, meaning that\nit only works if every node reaches an identical state after processing every\ntransaction and block.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">Everything that takes place on a blockchain\nmust be completely deterministic, with no possible way for differences to creep\nin.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">The moment that two honest nodes disagree about the chain's state, the\nentire system becomes worthless.</span></span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Now, recall that smart contracts are executed\nindependently by every node on a chain. Therefore, if a smart contract\nretrieves some information from an external source, this retrieval is performed\nrepeatedly and separately by each node.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">But because this source is outside of the\nblockchain, there is no guarantee that every node will receive the same answer.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Perhaps the source will change its response in the time between requests from\ndifferent nodes, or perhaps it will become temporarily unavailable. Either way,\nconsensus is broken and the entire blockchain dies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">So, what\u2019s the workaround? Actually, it\u2019s\nrather simple. Instead of a smart contract initiating the retrieval of external\ndata, one or more trusted parties (\"oracles\") creates a transaction\nwhich embeds that data in the chain. Every node will have an identical copy of\nthis data, so it can be safely used in a smart contract computation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In other words, as I have written before--an\noracle pushes the data onto the blockchain rather than a smart contract pulling\nit in.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">When it comes to smart contracts causing\nevents in the outside world, a similar problem appears. For example, many like\nthe idea of a smart contract which calls a bank\u2019s API in order to transfer\nmoney. But if every node is independently executing the code in the chain, who\nis responsible for calling this API?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">If the answer is just one node, what happens\nif that particular node malfunctions, deliberately or not? And if the answer is\nevery node, can we trust every node with that API's password? And do we really\nwant the API called hundreds of times?&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Even worse, if the smart contract needs\nto know whether the API call was successful, we're right back to the problem of\ndepending on external data.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">As before, a simple workaround is available.\nInstead of the smart contract calling an external API, we use a trusted service\nwhich monitors the blockchain\u2019s state and performs certain actions in response.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">For example, a bank could proactively watch a blockchain and perform money\ntransfers which mirror the on-chain transactions. This presents no risk to the\nblockchain\u2019s consensus because the chain plays an entirely passive role.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Looking at these two workarounds, we can make\nsome observations.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">First, they both require a trusted entity to\nmanage the interactions between the blockchain and the outside world. While\nthis is technically possible, it undermines the goal of a decentralized system.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Second, the mechanisms used in these\nworkarounds are straightforward examples of reading and writing a database. An\noracle which provides external information is simply writing that information\ninto the chain.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">And a service which mirrors the blockchain\u2019s state in the real\nworld is doing nothing more than reading from that chain. In other words, any\ninteraction between a blockchain and the outside world is restricted to regular\ndatabase operations.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Now\u2014about using a smart contract to automate\nthe payment of coupons for a so-called \"smart bond\". The idea is for\nthe smart contract code to automatically initiate the payments at the\nappropriate times, avoiding manual processes and guaranteeing that the issuer\ncannot default.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">Of course, in order for this to work, the\nfunds used to make the payments must live inside the blockchain as well,\notherwise a smart contract could not possibly guarantee their payment.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Recall that a blockchain is just a database,\nin this case a financial ledger containing the issued bond and some cash. So,\nwhen we talk about coupon payments, what we\u2019re actually talking about are\ndatabase operations which take place automatically at an agreed time.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">While this automation is technically\nfeasible, it suffers from a financial difficulty. If the funds used for coupon\npayments are controlled by the bond's smart contract, then those payments can\nindeed be guaranteed.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">But this also means those funds cannot be used by the\nbond issuer for anything else.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">And if those funds aren\u2019t under the control of\nthe smart contract, then there is no way in which payment can be guaranteed.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In other words, a smart bond is either\npointless for the issuer, or pointless for the investor. And if you think about\nit, this is a completely obvious outcome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">From an investor\u2019s perspective, the whole\npoint of a bond is its attractive rate of return, at the cost of some risk of\ndefault. And for the issuer, a bond's purpose is to raise funds for a\nproductive but somewhat risky activity, such as building a new factory.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">There is no way for the bond issuer to make\nuse of the funds raised, while simultaneously guaranteeing that the investor\nwill be repaid. It should not come as a surprise that the connection between\nrisk and return is not a problem that blockchains can solve.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">The biggest challenge in deploying\nblockchains is the radical transparency which they provide.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">For example, if 10 banks set up a blockchain\ntogether, and two conduct a bilateral transaction, this will be immediately\nvisible to the other eight.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">While there are various strategies for mitigating\nthis problem, none beat the simplicity and efficiency of a centralized database\nin which a trusted administrator has full control over who can see what.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Some people think that smart contracts can\nsolve this problem. They start with the fact that each smart contract contains\nits own miniature database, over which it has full control.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">All read and write\noperations on this database are mediated by the contract\u2019s code, making it\nimpossible for one contract to read another\u2019s data directly. (This tight\ncoupling between data and code is called encapsulation, and is the foundation\nof the popular object-oriented programming paradigm).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">So, if one smart contract can\u2019t access\nanother\u2019s data, have we solved the problem of blockchain confidentiality? Does\nit make sense to talk of hiding information in a smart contract? Unfortunately,\nthe answer is no.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">Because even if one smart contract can\u2019t read\nanother\u2019s data, that data is still stored on every single node in the chain.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">For each blockchain participant, it\u2019s in the memory or disk of a system which\nthat participant completely controls.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">And there\u2019s nothing to stop them reading\nthe information from their own system, if and when they choose to do so.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Hiding data in a smart contract is about as\nsecure as hiding it in the HTML code of a web page.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Sure, regular web users\nwon't see it, because it's not displayed in their browser window.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">But all it\ntakes is for a web browser to add a \u2018View Source\u2019 function (as they all have),\nand the information becomes universally visible.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">Similarly, for data hidden in smart\ncontracts, all it takes is for someone to modify their blockchain software to\ndisplay the contract\u2019s full state, and all semblance of secrecy is lost.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">A half wit programmer could do that in an\nhour or so.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The smart contract for a financial ledger\nperforms the same three tasks as the administrator of a centralized database:\nchecking for sufficient funds, deducting from one account and adding to\nanother.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Both of these paradigms are effective, and\neach has its advantages and disadvantages. To summarize, bitcoin-style\ntransaction constraints provide superior concurrency and performance, while\nEthereum-style smart contracts offer greater flexibility.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">So to return to the question of what smart\ncontracts are for: Smart contracts are for blockchain use cases which can\u2019t be\nimplemented with transaction constraints.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Given this criterion for using smart\ncontracts, I\u2019m yet to see a strong use case for permissioned blockchains which\nqualifies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In 2016, the Decentralized Autonomous\nOrganization (DAO) announced that a hacker had exploited a vulnerability in\nEthereum, a blockchain platform utilized by the group. The total loss to the\nDAO was reported at $150 million.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The flaw was not in the blockchain platform\nitself, but rather in the smart contract. The hacker was able to trigger a\nrecursive send vulnerability where the act of sending funds triggered another\n\u201csend funds\u201d request.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Etherium had done exactly what it was supposed to do, but\na loophole in the smart contract code exposed the organization to a hack. It\nwas reported that the DAO lost $60 million in just the first 12 hours.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Remember that there are no standards for\ntesting smart contracts, and having \u201cadequate\u201d testing exposes the company to\npotential risk.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">Smart contracts are only as smart as the\nprogramming code on which they are based..&nbsp; &nbsp; The DAO hack was enabled by a\nvulnerability in the code of the blockchain\u2019s smart contract.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The attacker\u2019s\nknowledge of a particular feature in the code demonstrated that such an\nasymmetry in information could prove to be a lucrative, if nefarious or even illegal,\ncompetitive advantage.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Blockchain technology lacks a history of\nsecure code, and specialists have not yet had enough time to anticipate what\nthose flaws might be. Others, too, have suggested that smart contracts be\nwritten, tested, and deployed in well-defined processes with strong controls\naround them<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Yet, some have cautioned against the\nimplementation of too many security protection measures, which would decrease\nthe efficiency of the blockchain and may obviate the value of the technology in\nthe first place.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;Blockchain, &nbsp;cannot entirely eliminate or automate the\nhuman dimension of trust.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">The stability of the entire blockchain depends on its\nusers placing stock in the individuals who able to verify the code, thereby\nensuring that smart contracts will be executed as intended.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The democratic nature of the blockchain and\nthe current application of smart contracts might be a double-edged sword: while\nusers at the base of the pyramid may benefit from some reductions in\ntransaction costs as a result of less intermediation, without lawyers and other\nmiddlemen, it is unclear what protections or legal recourse these users would\nhave in the event that their blockchain-enabled transactions are compromised.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Furthermore, if even highly financially-literate and tech-savvy consumers\ncannot see fatal flaws in the smart contract code, can we reasonably expect\nless financially- and technically-literate users at the base of the pyramid to\ncatch these same mistakes, even if the code is theoretically open to the public\neye?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">And even if users at the base of the pyramid\ncould afford the services of lawyers who were well-versed in blockchain and\nsmart contract coding, can we really be certain these individuals could\nrecognize and enforce airtight smart contracts?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">It is na\u00efve, and even dangerous, to take an\noverly optimistic and utopian vision of blockchain and smart contract\ntechnology without further scrutiny of these unresolved fundamental issues on\nthe alignment of economic incentives of users, consensus mechanisms, and trust.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Smart contracts are pieces of code that\nleverage the power of the Blockchain technology to facilitate, verify, or\nenforce the negotiation or performance of contracts.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Smart contracts &nbsp;are pieces of software, not contracts in the\nlegal sense, that extend blockchains\u2019 utility from simply keeping a record of\nfinancial transaction entries to automatically implementing terms of multiparty\nagreements.&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Smart contracts are executed by a computer\nnetwork that uses consensus protocols to agree upon the sequence of actions\nresulting from the contract\u2019s code<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-OZaHVuvjtUQ/Wfk_k0O8SBI/AAAAAAABWcA/T70irZYqiscK7pBWTa9PybN-_zpctIcqQCLcBGAs/s1600/teDmp_image-14.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"360\" data-original-width=\"480\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-OZaHVuvjtUQ/Wfk_k0O8SBI/AAAAAAABWcA/T70irZYqiscK7pBWTa9PybN-_zpctIcqQCLcBGAs/s640/teDmp_image-14.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The Ethereum network, which is valued at\naround 32 Billion USD, is struggling to deal with scaling issues despite its\nlack of actual user base<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Initial coin offering (ICO) is an unregulated\nand controversial means of crowdfunding via use of cryptocurrency which can be\na source of capital for startup companies. In an ICO a percentage of the newly\nissued cryptocurrency is sold to investors in exchange for legal tender or\nother cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The term may be analogous with 'token\nsale' or crowdsale, which refers to a method of selling participation in an\neconomy, giving investors access to the features of a particular project\nstarting at a later date. ICOs may sell a right of ownership or royalties to a\nproject.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The success of initial coin offerings (ICOs)\nas a new fundraising model is undoubtedly attracting an influx of tech talent\nto develop on Ethereum and other blockchain protocols. With over $1.25B raised\nthis year to date, ICOs have surpassed early-stage venture capital funding.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Furthermore, teams have raised tens of millions of dollars with only simple\nwhitepapers describing their ideas. Some ideas are truly innovative and have\ncaptured the public\u2019s imagination regarding what is theoretically possible with\nsmart contracts. In practice, however, the vast majority of ICOs are for\nprojects that are not yet feasible due to the technical limitations of blockchains.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Blockchains, as it stands today, are limited\nin their ability to scale.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Blockchains may be suitable for some niche\nuse cases, but they do not work well for mainstream use due to scaling issues. Bitcoin\nand Ethereum are only processing three and five transactions per second (tx/s),\nrespectively. To support Visa, Ethereum would need to scale to thousands of\ntx/s<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">While a decentralization consensus mechanism\noffers some critical benefits, such as fault tolerance, a strong guarantee of\nsecurity, political neutrality, and authenticity, it comes at the cost of\nscalability.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">The number of transactions the blockchain can process can never\nexceed that of a single node that is participating in the network. In fact, the\nblockchain actually gets weaker as more nodes are added to its network because\nof the inter-node latency that logarithmically increases with every additional\nnode.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In a traditional database system, the\nsolution to scalability is to add more servers (i.e. compute power) to handle\nthe added transactions. In the decentralized blockchain world where every node\nneeds to process and validate every transaction, it would require us to add\nmore compute to every node for the network to get faster. Having no control\nover every public node in the network leaves us up shit creek without a paddle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">As a result, all public blockchain consensus\nprotocols that operate in such a decentralized manner make the tradeoff between\nlow transaction throughput and high degree of centralization.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In other words,\nas the size of the blockchain grows, the requirements for storage, bandwidth,\nand compute power required by fully participating in the network increases. At\nsome point, it becomes unwieldy enough that it\u2019s only feasible for a few nodes\nto process a block\u200a\u2014\u200aleading to the risk of centralization.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In order to scale, the blockchain protocol\nmust figure out a mechanism to limit the number of participating nodes needed\nto validate each transaction, without losing the network\u2019s trust that each\ntransaction is valid. It might sound simple in words, but is technologically\nvery difficult.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Since every node is not allowed to validate\nevery transaction, we somehow need nodes to have a statistical and economic\nmeans to ensure that other blocks (which they are not personally validating) are\nsecure.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Even if a block looks valid from the\nperspective of a node not directly validating that block, making the data for\nthat block unavailable leads to a situation where no other validator in the\nnetwork can validate transactions or produce new blocks, and we end up stuck in\nthe current state. (There are several reasons a node might go offline,\nincluding malicious attack and power loss.)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Transactions need to be processed by\ndifferent nodes in parallel in order to achieve scalability.
